item.title: Trump and Schumer Move Toward Possible Deal to Avert a Shutdown
item.description: The president and the top Senate Democrat were discussing an agreement to split off homeland security funding from a broader spending package and negotiate new limits on immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Another Top Kennedy Center Official Resigns
item.description: Kevin Couch, who was announced as senior vice president of artistic programming less than two weeks ago, is the latest to leave since President Trump took control of the center last year.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of The Kennedy Center this month.

item.title: Shooting Aftermath Leaves Homeland Security Department in Turmoil
item.description: As officials point fingers in the wake of Alex Pretti’s death at the hands of federal agents, concerns grow about the agency’s future.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clearing protesters from a hotel in Minneapolis on Sunday night.

item.title: The Journey of a Group of Cuban Deportees Stuck at Guantánamo
item.description: The tale illustrates how inefficient the ICE operation has been in the year since President Trump ordered the base to prepare for up to 30,000 “criminal aliens.”
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An upper tier at Camp 6 detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in 2019. It is a former prison for Al Qaeda suspects, which now houses dozens of Cuban men designated for deportation from the United States.

item.title: Videos Show Alex Pretti in Confrontation With Agents 11 Days Before His Death
item.description: More than a week before federal agents killed Mr. Pretti, a Minneapolis nurse, different agents pushed him to the ground after he spit at them and broke a taillight on their S.U.V.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to Alex Pretti, who was fatally shot by immigration agents on Saturday, at the site where he was killed in South Minneapolis.

item.title: Judge Orders Release of Minnesota Refugees Targeted in ICE Crackdown
item.description: A federal judge granted a temporary restraining order, which halts a Trump administration operation that has swept up at least 100 people so far.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Federal agents arrested a man after pursuing him on foot in Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: The Trump administration moves to sell a landmark D.C. building that was once a Trump hotel.
item.description: The Old Post Office, a 19th-century building in the nation’s capital with an iconic clock tower, was once home to the Trump International Hotel.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump International Hotel in Washington became a Waldorf Astoria in 2022.

item.title: The Man ICE Agents Were Seeking When They Killed Alex Pretti Remains at Large
item.description: Federal officials said agents were looking for an Ecuadorean named Jose Huerta-Chuma. Records show he faced allegations of domestic assault and had several traffic infractions.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Pooja Salhotra
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino, right, and other immigration officials have cast their deportation campaign as a hunt for criminals.

item.title: Trump Administration Denies That Coercion Is at Heart of Minnesota ICE Surge
item.description: A federal judge weighing whether to block the immigration surge asked Justice Department lawyers to more fully explain the reasons for the operation.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents detaining a man outside his home on Tuesday in St. Paul, Minn., amid an immigration operation.

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: America at a Boiling Point: From ICE Protests to an Attack on Rep. Omar
item.description: An attack at a town hall in Minneapolis, amid a surge in threats against lawmakers, was the latest sign of the fraying of the nation’s political fabric.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ilhan Omar after being sprayed with a foul-smelling liquid by an assailant at a town hall on Tuesday night in Minneapolis.

item.title: Homelessness Appears to Decline, Reversing a Yearslong Trend
item.description: The Trump administration has not yet released the count, which could complicate its plans for tough new policies.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless encampment in Chicago in March 2024. Local data collected by The New York Times showed that homelessness fell 60 percent in Chicago in the last year of the Biden administration.

item.title: Democrats Demand Unmasked Agents, New Limits to Fund D.H.S.
item.description: Ahead of a Friday shutdown deadline, Democrats laid out their conditions for funding the Department of Homeland Security, including new restrictions on immigration officers.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the minority leader, presented Republicans with a specific proposal that Democrats said they would insist on in exchange for their votes.

item.title: Judge Scolds Bondi for Publishing Photos of Protesters on Social Media
item.description: “This conduct is not something that the court condones,” Judge Dulce J. Foster said during a hearing in a Minneapolis federal court.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Federal agents arresting a protester in Minneapolis this month.

item.title: Judge in Minnesota Says ICE Has Violated Nearly 100 Court Orders
item.description: A federal judge said ICE had disobeyed more judicial directives this month than “some federal agencies have violated in their entire existence.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Federal agents arrested and carried a protester in south Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: Sergey Brin Spends $20 Million on California Political Effort Amid Wealth Tax Debate
item.description: Sergey Brin donated $20 million to a new political drive aimed at solving California’s housing crisis, spurring other billionaires to pitch in. Their efforts may also help ward off a wealth tax.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:description: Sergey Brin’s group says it is trying to solve problems and help middle-class workers pay for housing in a state where the median home price has surpassed $850,000.

item.title: 5 Key Takeaways from Josh Shapiro’s Memoir ‘Where We Keep the Light’
item.description: Politically pointed and heavy on his Jewish faith, the book already has Democrats talking.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania

item.title: ‘No Win’ for Minneapolis Police Caught Between Trump and City Residents
item.description: With the Trump administration accusing local police of dereliction and some in the community feeling unprotected, outnumbered Minneapolis officers find themselves facing difficult choices.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:description: A Minneapolis police officer stands on duty at an intersection near the spot where Renee Good was shot and killed earlier this month.

item.title: Attack on Ilhan Omar Follows Years of Trump’s Targeting Her
item.description: President Trump has spent years demonizing and dehumanizing the Somali-born Democrat from Minnesota, fueling escalating threats against her.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, speaking before a man sprayed her with a liquid at a town hall event in Minneapolis on Tuesday night.

item.title: Tens of Thousands in Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana Without Power After Storm
item.description: Across Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana, hundreds of power lines and poles remained damaged after freezing rain and low temperatures coated much of the region in ice over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Linemen work to restore power in Oxford, Miss., on Monday.

item.title: Who Is the Man That Attacked Ilhan Omar at a Town Hall in Minneapolis?
item.description: Anthony J. Kazmierczak frequently posted online about conservative issues. He told a neighbor that he was going to get arrested at an event hosted by Ms. Omar.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police say Anthony Kazmierczak, center, used a syringe to spray Representative Ilhan Omar with a liquid at a town hall in Minneapolis on Tuesday night before he was tackled by security officers.

item.title: Chinese National Heng Guan Who Documented Uyghurs’ Repression Wins Asylum
item.description: Heng Guan, a Chinese national, will not be released immediately, as Homeland Security said it was reserving the right to appeal.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin

item.title: Three Boys Die After Falling Through Icy Pond in Texas
item.description: Two 16-year-old girls in northern Texas were also killed in the aftermath of the winter storm when their sled, pulled by a Jeep, crashed into a tree, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: Cook Children's Medical Center (Fort Worth, Tex)

item.title: Republicans Gave ICE a Slush Fund. Democrats Want to Limit It.
item.description: The sweeping domestic policy law that Republicans muscled through Congress last year made ICE the highest-funded federal law enforcement agency in the country, with no strings attached.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis on Tuesday.

item.title: Their Mother Was Detained. Now a Minneapolis Family Lives in Fear.
item.description: After a Minneapolis woman was arrested by ICE agents, the children she left behind face an uncertain future. In the days following their mother’s detainment, the oldest daughter spoke to The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Ang Li, Bethlehem Feleke, Ben Garvin and Caroline Kim
item.media:credit: Ben Garvin for The New York Times

item.title: Federal Officers Who Fired at Pretti Placed on Leave
item.description: A Border Patrol agent and a Customs and Border Protection officer have been on leave since Saturday, according to a Department of Homeland Security official.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: Federal officers and protesters faced off in Minneapolis on Saturday, shortly after agents shot and killed Alex Pretti, a Minneapolis man, that morning.

item.title: U.S. allies in the Middle East have been pressing for weeks to prevent a conflict with Iran.
item.description: Diplomats in the region have spent weeks trying to prevent a confrontation that they say risks a wider conflict.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The USS Abraham Lincoln, a Nimitz-class nuclear-powered aircraft carrier in San Diego last year. The USS Abraham Lincoln is part of what President Trump has descried as an armada poised to strike near Iran.

item.title: For Minneapolis’s Native Americans, a New Fight Echoes a Bitter History
item.description: The crackdown on unauthorized immigrants is resonating deeply among the Dakota and other tribes, as residents confront what they call a federal occupation of their land.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Purdy
item.media:description: Sophie Watso, of the Mdewakanton Dakota tribe, was arrested in a dispute with federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Trump Officials’ Use of ‘Domestic Terrorist’ in Minnesota Shootings Doesn’t Match Legal Reality
item.description: The Trump administration has used the term as a cudgel against political adversaries, especially this month to defend immigration officers who had killed two protesters in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance characterized the actions of Renee Good, one of the two demonstrators killed this month, as “classic terrorism.”

item.title: F.B.I. Agents Search Georgia Election Center
item.description: F.B.I. agents searched a Fulton County, Ga., election center for ballots from 2020, escalating an investigation of a heavily Democratic jurisdiction the president has criticized over his defeat.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Votes are counted in November 2024 at the election hub and operations center in Fulton County in Union City, Ga.

item.title: Trump Threatens Iran With ‘Massive Armada’ and Presses a Set of Demands
item.description: U.S. and European officials say they have put three demands in front of the Iranians, including a permanent end to all enrichment of uranium.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The USS Abraham Lincoln in 2024. The aircraft carrier group is currently stationed in striking distance of targets in Iran.

item.title: How Battlefield Tech Was Used in Minneapolis
item.description: Our reporter Thomas Gibbons-Neff, who deployed twice to Afghanistan as a Marine and later was our Kabul bureau chief, looks at the battlefield technology used for an immigration arrest at a home in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Leila Medina and Coleman Lowndes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Did Trump Really Change His Mind on Minnesota?
item.description: Our White House reporter Tyler Pager describes how while President Trump appeared to soften his tone on Minnesota after seeing outrage over the killing of Alex Pretti, the crackdown continues on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Leila Medina and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Stephen Miller Suggests Federal Agents May Have Diverted From ‘Protocol’ Before Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The comments by Mr. Miller, the influential White House deputy chief of staff, came after days of blaming Alex Pretti, who was fatally shot by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.media:description: Stephen Miller at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Is Ilhan Omar, the Lawmaker Attacked in Minnesota?
item.description: Ms. Omar, a Democratic member of Congress, has come under fire for years, most notably from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ilhan Omar

item.title: Trump threatens Iran again and calls for negotiations on a nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran depicts strikes on an American aircraft carrier.

item.title: To Combat Fake Water Filters, GE Appliances Opens Own U.S. Factory
item.description: Refrigerator manufacturers have been battling counterfeit filters for years. Now GE Appliances is taking the fight up a notch.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Angela Shoemaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A GE plant in Louisville, Ky., in 2014. GE Appliances is opening a factory in the city to make water filters for its refrigerators.

item.title: Nervous Allies and Fox News: How Trump Realized He Had a Big Problem in Minneapolis
item.description: President Trump often blusters his way through a crisis, refusing to back down. Minneapolis tested the limits of that strategy.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: President Trump has honed a survival tactic over many years facing criticism in the public eye.

item.title: Ecuador Objects After ICE Agent Tries to Enter Minneapolis Consulate
item.description: Video showed diplomatic staff blocking the agent from entering on Tuesday morning.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Ali Watkins

item.title: Doomsday Clock Ticks Closer Than Ever to Apocalypse
item.description: Wars, climate change, disruptive technologies and the rise of autocracy over the past year prompted scientists to set the clock at 85 seconds to midnight.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The Doomsday Clock of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists was displayed during a news conference at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Alan Feuer

item.title: ICE Agents Bring Military-Grade Weapons to Minnesota Doorsteps
item.description: In pursuit of illegal immigrants, federal agents are carrying the instruments of war, fine-tuned and perfected for killing at short range.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives

item.title: As Minneapolis Rages, Legislators Move to Restrict ICE in Their States
item.description: Efforts to curtail federal law enforcement tactics began last year, but with the deaths of Alex Pretti and Renee Good, Democratic lawmakers are pushing harder.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen

item.title: How We Tracked Down Thousands of Police Misconduct Files
item.description: Freedom of Information requests led to the discovery of varied offenses by officers around New York State.
item.dc:creator: Sammy Sussman
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Starting in 1976, New York State, by law, kept most police personnel records secret. But when the law was repealed in 2020, many departments began making their records available.

item.title: How the Online SAT May be Vulnerable to Cheating
item.description: Sites in China are selling test questions, and online forums offer software that can bypass test protections, according to tutors and testing experts raising alarms.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: A student taking a practice SAT test.

item.title: Loose Rules Let New York State Police Hand Out Lax Penalties for Serious Misconduct
item.description: New York State troopers used the badge to settle personal scores and elicit favors. Still, they remained on the job, an investigation found.
item.dc:creator: Sammy Sussman
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: State Police troopers are often brought in to aid local law enforcement in serious cases. But disciplinary files revealed a lack of scrutiny when the department policed its own.
